title-group.article-title: Terpenoids from the Chinese liverwort Odontoschisma grosseverrucosum and their antifungal virulence activity

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Terpenoids from the Chinese liverwort
Odontoschisma grosseverrucosum
and their antifungal virulence activity

sec.title: Orphanage

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p:
Odontoschisma grosseverrucosum Stephani
(cephaloziaceae)
Liverworts
Terpenoids
Odongrossin A−H
Anti-virulence
A B S T R A C T

Eight undescribed terpenoids, namely, odongrossins A−H, together with two known terpenoids were isolated from
Odontoschisma grosseverrucosum Stephani (Cephaloziaceae)
. Their structures were established based on NMR data, electronic circular dichroism (ECD) calculations, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements. Odongrossin A and odongrossin G displayed moderate anti-virulence activities against CDR1 -and CDR2 -efflux-pump-deficient
Candida albicans DSY
654. Further investigation of odongrossin A revealed that it inhibited adhesion and biofilm formation on
C. albicans DSY
654. The results regarding the transcription levels of genes demonstrated that odongrossin A could regulate the expression of genes that are associated with the virulence of
C. albicans DSY
654.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
Herein, we report in detail the isolation and structural elucidation of eight previously undescribed terpenoids (which include two rare dilospirane-type diterpenoids) ( 1–8 ), together with two known congeners ( 9–10 ) ( Fig. 1 ) that were isolated from the liverwort
Odontoschisma grosseverrucosum Stephani (Cephaloziaceae)
, which was collected from Wuyanling National Nature Reserve, Lishui City, Zhejiang Province , People's Republic of China , and the evaluation of their antifungal virulence activity.

sec.title: 2.1. Structure elucidation
sec.p:
Odongrossin A ( 1 ) was obtained as a yellowish oil. The molecular formula of 1 , namely, C 20 H 34 O 2 ( m/z 329.2452 [M + Na] + , calcd 329.2451), which has four degrees of unsaturation, was established based on its HRESIMS data. The IR spectrum showed absorptions at 3504 and 1713 cm −1 , which were due to one hydroxyl group and one carbonyl group, respectively. The 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) showed signals of five methyl groups [ δ H 0.82 (d, J = 6.8 Hz, H 3 -19), 0.92 (d, J = 6.8 Hz, H 3 -18), 1.05 (s, H 3 -20), 1.08 (s, H 3 -16) and 2.13 (s, H 3 -15)] and two highly shielded methines, which were attributed to a tetrasubstituted cyclopropane ring [ δ H 0.22 (ddd, J = 10.1, 6.9, 5.5 Hz, H-9), and 0.32 (dt, J = 7.1, 5.1 Hz, H-11)]. The 13 C NMR ( Table 3 ) and the HSQC spectra revealed 20 carbon signals, which were attributed to five methyls, seven methylenes, four methines (including one oxygenated methine; δ C
60.1), and four quaternary carbons (including an oxygenated quaternary carbon and a ketone carbonyl; δ C
85.6 and 209.5, respectively). Due to the presence of one carbonyl group, the four degrees of unsaturation demonstrated that 1 was a tricyclic structure. The NMR spectroscopic data of 1 closely resembled that of dilospirane B (
), except for the presence of signals for an oxygenated quaternary carbon at δ C
85.6 and a methyl group [0.92 (d, J = 6.8 Hz, H 3 -18); δ C
17.5] in 1 . The presence of a tetrasubstituted ternary ring was supported by HMBC correlations from H 3 - 20 to C-8, C-9 and C-11, and from H-11 to C-7, C-8, C-9, C-10 and C-20, along with the linkage moiety CH (9)− CH (11) from the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-9 ( δ H 0.22)/H-11 ( δ H 0.32). These data provided evidence of one hydroxyl group at C-4, and the double bond between C-17 and C-18 was hydrogenated in 1 . This was also supported by the HMBC correlations from H 3 -19 to C-4, C-17 and C-18. Odongrossin A has been regarded as an unnamed skeleton, which we wish to name the dilospirane skeleton since dilospirane B features previously described carbocyclic units (
). This was the first dilospiranetype diterpenoid that was isolated from liverworts. The NOESY correlations (Fig. S6) of H 3 -16/H-9 and H-9/H 3 -20 indicated that they were co-facial, and they were assigned as α -oriented. The NOESY correlations of H 3 -20/H-7 α , H-7 β /H-5 and H-7 β /H-11 indicated that H-5 and H-11 were β -oriented. The NOESY correlation of OH-4/H 3 -16 recorded in DMSO‑ d 6 (Fig. S7) indicated that OH-4 was α -oriented. Accordingly, the relative configuration of 1 was supported. The experimental ECD spectrum perfectly accorded with the trends of the calculated curves for 1 (Fig. S83 A ). Thus, the absolute configuration of 1 was assigned as 1 S , 4 S , 5 S , 8 R , 9 S , 11 S .
Chemical shifts ( δ ) are expressed in ppm, and J values are presented in Hz. a Recorded at 600 MHz in CDCl.

The chemical formula of odongrossin B ( 2 ), which is a yellowish oil, namely, C 18 H 32 O 2 ( m/z 281.2477 [M + H] + , (calcd 281.2475) was established based on HRESIMS data, which suggested that it had one fewer degree of unsaturation than 1 . The IR spectrum showed absorptions at 3351 cm −1 , which were due to hydroxyl groups. The NMR spectroscopic data of 2 ( Tables 1 and 3 ) exhibited similar characteristic signals to those of 1 , except for the presence of a signal for oxygenated methylene at δ C
63.7 and the disappearance of a ketone carbonyl and a methyl. These data provided evidence that the acetyl group at C- 13 in 1 was replaced by one hydroxyl group in 2 . Herein, a degraded dilospirane-type diterpenoid skeleton was suggested. The relative configuration of 2 was assigned to be the same as that of 1 based on similar NOESY correlations (Fig. S17) of H-9/H 3 -20 ( δ H 1.07), H-9/H 3 -16 ( δ H 1.10), H 3 -20/H-7 α , H-7 β /H-5, and H-7 β /H-11. The NOESY correlation of OH-4/H
3 -16 in
DMSO‑ d 6 indicated that OH-4 was α -oriented (Fig. S18). The ECD data (Fig. S83 A ) of 2 were consistent with those of 1, which supported the absolute structure of 1 S , 4 S , 5 S , 8 S , 9 S , 11 S . Odongrossin B was demonstrated to be an enantiomerically pure compound via liquid chromatography (HPLC) analyses on a Waters Delta 600 system with a chiral column and a Waters 996 photodiode array detector (Fig. S85).

Odongrossin C ( 3 ) was isolated as colourless needles. The molecular formula of 3 , namely, C 16 H 20 O 3 , as determined by HRESIMS ( m/z 283.1305 [M + Na] + , calcd 283.1305) and 13 C NMR data, corresponds to seven degrees of unsaturation. The IR absorption band at 1764 cm −1 suggested the presence of a carbonyl functional group. An analysis of the 1D NMR data ( Tables 1 and 3 ) of 3 and the HSQC spectrum revealed 16 carbon signals that were attributable to four methyls (one methoxyl at δ C
55.5), one methylene, four sp 3 methines (one oxygenated at δ C
76.5), two sp 2 methines ( δ C
107.9 and 130.8), and five quaternary methines (four olefinic carbons at δ C
125.5, 126.4, 138.6 and 157.1, and one carbonyl at δ C
179.1). Herein, a cadinane-type (bicycle [4.4.0] decane) sesquiterpenoid skeleton (
) was suggested. A benzene ring was determined from the HMBC correlations from H 3 -15 ( δ H 2.20) to C-2, C-3 and C-4, from H-4 to C-2 and C-6, and from H-1 to C-2, C-3 and C-5. The 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-7/H 2 -8, H 2 -8/ H-9 and H-9/H-10, along with the key HMBC correlations from H 3 -14 ( δ H 1.42) to C-6, C-7 and C-8, led to the identification of a hexatomic ring. The NMR spectroscopic data of 3 were similar to that of 2- methoxy-calamenene-14-carboxylic acid (
), except for the appearance of an oxygenated methine, as judged by the carbon resonance at δ C
76.5. These data provided evidence of a lactone ring between C-9 and C- 12 in 3 . This was also supported by the HMBC correlations from H 3 -13 ( δ H 1.51) to C-10, C-11 and C-12, and from H-9 to C-11 and C-12. Thus, the planar structure of 3 was elucidated. NOESY correlations of H-9/H-7 and H 3 -13/H-10, together with single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis with Mo K α radiation ( Fig. 2C ), were used to assign the relative configuration of 3 . The absolute configuration of 3 was determined by comparing the experimental and calculated ECD spectra (Fig. S83B). Thus, the stereochemistry of 3 was identified as 7 S , 9 R , 10 S , 11 R .

Odongrossin D ( 4 ) was obtained as a colourless oil. The HRESIMS spectrum showed the [M + Na] + ion peak at m/z 327.2294 (calcd 327.2295) was ascribed to the molecular formula C 20 H 32 O 2 , which corresponds to five degrees of unsaturation. The IR spectrum showed absorptions at 3463 and 1708 cm −1 , which were due to one hydroxyl group and one carbonyl group, respectively. The 1 H NMR spectrum ( Table 2 ) displayed the signals of four methyls at δ H 1.29 (s, H 3 -16), 0.90 (d, J = 6.7 Hz, H 3 -17), 1.01 (s, H 3 -19), and 0.71 (s, H 3 -20), along with a monosubstituted vinyl (– CH ] CH 2 ) at δ H 5.89 (dd, J = 17.4, 10.8 Hz, H-14), 5.09 (dd, J = 10.8, 0.9 Hz, H-15a) and 5.23 (dd, J = 17.4, 0.9 Hz, H-15 b). Additionally, one disubstituted vinyl at δ H 4.56 (br s, H-18a) and 4.43 (br s, H-18 b) was observed. The 13 C NMR ( Table 3 ) and HSQC spectra supported the presence of two terminal double bond ( δ C
158.2, 103.2; 144.9, 112.4), a carbonyl ketone at C-7 ( δ C
214.2), and an oxygenated quaternary carbon ( δ C
73.3). A clerodane-type diterpenoid skeleton (
) was suggested. The data of 4 corresponded to a similar structure to that of chelodane (
), except for the appearance of a carbonyl ketone, as judged by the carbon resonance at δ C
214.2. The HMBC correlations from H 2 -6 to C-7 and from H-8 to C-7 indicated that the carbonyl was located at C-7. The NOESY correlations (Fig. S38) of H 3 -17/H 3 -20 and H 3 -20/H 3 -19 indicated that they were co-facial and α -oriented. The NOESY correlation of H-10/H-8 indicated the β -orientation of the two protons. Accordingly, the relative configuration of 4 was determined. The absolute configuration was further supported by ECD calculations, as presented in Fig. S83 C . Thus, 4 was identified as 5 R , 8 S , 9 R , 10 R .

Odongrossin E ( 5 ) was isolated as a colourless oil, and it was assigned the molecular formula C 20 H 34 O 2 based on its HRESIMS data ( m/ z 306.2550 [M] + , calcd 306.2553) and 13 C NMR spectrum, which corresponds to four degrees of unsaturation. The NMR spectroscopic data of 5 ( Tables 2 and 3 ) exhibited similar characteristic signals to those of 4 , except that the ketone carbonyl group at C- 7 in 4 was replaced by a hydroxyl group in 5 , which was further supported by the HMBC correlations (Fig. S46) from H 3 -17 ( δ H 0.98) to C-7 ( δ C
73.7) and by the observation of spin system CH 2 (6)− CH (7)− CH (8) in the 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum. The NOESY correlations of H-10/H-8, H-8/H-6 β , H-6 α / H 3 -19 ( δ H 1.34), H 3 -19/H 3 -20 ( δ H 1.00) and H 3 -17/H-7 demonstrated that the relative configuration of 5 was consistent with that of 4 . Moreover, the CD curve (Fig. S52) of 5 showed the same trend as that of 4 . Accordingly, the stereochemistry of 5 was established as 5 R , 7 S , 8 S , 9 R , 10 R .

Odongrossin F ( 6 ) was obtained as a colourless oil, and it was assigned the same molecular formula as 5 based on its HRESIMS data ( m/ z 306.2550 [M] + , calcd 306.2553), which corresponds to four degrees of unsaturation. The NMR spectroscopic data ( Tables 2 and 3 ) of 6 closely resembled that of 5 , except that the location of the hydroxyl group at C- 7 in 5 shifted to C-6 ( δ C
74.2) in 6 , which was further supported by the HMBC correlations (Fig. S56) from H 3 -19 ( δ H 1.06) to C-6 and by the spin system CH (6)− CH 2 (7)− CH (8) that was observed in the 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum. Accordingly, the planar structure of 6 was established. The relative configuration of 6 was determined by the NOESY correlations of H 3 -19/H 3 -20 ( δ H 0.72), H 3 -20/H 3 -17 ( δ H 0.81), H-8/H-10 and H-10/H-6, which was consistent with that of 4 . According to the CD data (Fig. S62), the absolute configuration of 6 was identified as 5 R , 6 S , 8 R , 9 S , 10 R .
Chemical shifts ( δ ) are expressed in ppm, and J values are presented in Hz.
a Recorded at 600 MHz in CDCl.
3 b Recorded at 400 MHz in CDCl.
a Data were measured in CDCl at 150 MHz.
3 b Data were measured in CDCl at 100 MHz.

sec.title: 2.2. Results on the anti-virulence activity of the compounds
sec.p:
Candida albicans
has developed numerous virulence factors for causing disease in a host, such as hyphal formation, adhesion, and biofilm formation. The targeting of virulence factors has been proposed as a potential therapy for candidiasis (
). Thus, we evaluated the effects of compounds 1–10 on the morphological transitions of
C. albicans DSY
654 and wild-type strain SC 5314 (
). The results demonstrated that compounds 1 and 7 exhibited antifungal activity by inhibiting the hyphal formation of DSY 654 ( Table S1 ). Between them, 1 displayed the more potent inhibitory effect, which could restrict
C. albicans
in yeast form at the concentration of 16 μ g/mL within 6 h ( Fig. 3A ). Therefore, we investigate the inhibitory performance of 1 against adhesion and biofilm formation. The results demonstrated that 1 exhibited potent, dose-dependent inhibitory activity against the adhesion and biofilm formation of
C. albicans
( Fig. 3B, C, 3D, and 3E ). Above all, 1 has the potential to inhibit adhesion, hyphal formation and biofilm formation of
C. albicans
.

To identify the underlying mechanisms of the inhibited morphological transition, we investigated the transcription levels of genes that are related to the hyphal formation and cell adhesion in
C. albicans
using real-time RT-PCR. According to Fig. 3F , the expressions of adhesion-related genes ( HWP1 , ECE1 and ALS3 ) were downregulated by 1 at 6 h. Furthermore, the hyphae-formation-regulated genes in the Ras1-cAMP-PKA signalling pathway were downregulated to varying extents, as CDC35 was downregulated in the presence of 1 , which can result in a decrease of the intracellular cAMP content. In addition, the genes that are associated with the MAPKA pathway ( CST20 and HST7 ) and transcription factors ( TEC1, UME6, and BCR1 ) were downregulated to varying extents. These results suggest that 1 likely regulates the expression of genes that are related to the virulence of
C. albicans
to retard the yeast-to-hyphae transition.

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p:
In summary, eight previously undescribed terpenoids ( 1–8 ), which include a dilospirane skeleton in compounds 1–2 , a cadinane skeleton in compound 3 , a clerodane skeleton in compounds 4–6 , a vibsane skeleton in compound 7 and a dolabrane skeleton in compound 8 , together with two known terpenoids ( 9–10 ) were isolated from
O. grosseverrucosum
. A plausible biogenetic pathway of compounds 1–3 and 7 was proposed ( Fig. 4 ). The characteristic skeleton of compound 1 was derived from dolastane diterpenoid (
) via selective oxidation, C 9 – C 14 cleavage and cyclopropanation, and compound 2 was transformed from 1 under Baeyer-Villiger type oxidation condition. The aromatic rings and lactone of compound 3 possessed cadinane sesquiterpenoid framework (
) could be constructed by aromatization and C- 12 oxidation, respectively. Compound 7 was formed similarly through late-stage oxidation and functionalization of vibsane diterpenoid. Two compounds could inhibit the yeast-filamentous growth transition of
C. albicans DSY
654 to various degrees but were inactive against SC 5314. Additional studies of 1 suggested that it could significantly attenuate the virulence of
C. albicans
by inhibiting hyphal formation, adhesion, and biofilm formation and by regulating the expression of virulence-related genes. Thus, searching for PEPSs from liverworts may be an efficient strategy for discovering previously undescribed compounds for fighting clinically relevant fungal infections.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
sec.p: Optical rotations were acquired by an Anton Paar MCP 200 polarimeter at 20 ° C . HRESIMS data ( 1 , 3 , 4 , 7 and 8 ) were obtained using a Thermo Electron LTQ-Orbitrap XL, and HRESIMS data ( 2 , 5 and 6 ) were obtained using an Agilent 6520 Series Accurate-Mass Q-TOF LC/ MS. ECD spectra were obtained using a Chirascan spectropolarimeter. UV data were recorded using a UV-2550 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan ). IR spectra were measured on a Nicolet iN 10 Micro FTIR spectrometer. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance DRX-600 spectrometer ( 1 H: 600 MHz, 13 C : 150 MHz) and a Bruker Avance AVIII-400 spectrometer (1H: 400 MHz, 13 C : 100 MHz) using TMS as an internal standard. HPLC was conducted on an Agilent 1200-series instrument with ZORBAX SB-C 18 5 μ m columns (4.6 × 250 mm and 9.4 × 250 mm ). HPLC analyses of 2 were conducted on a Waters Delta 600 system with a CHIRALPAK AD-H 5 μ m column (4.6 × 250 mm ) and a Waters 996 photodiode array detector. MCI gel (CHP20P, 75–150 mm , Mitsubishi Chemical Industries Ltd.), silica gel (200–300 mesh; Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Co. Ltd.), Sephadex LH-20 (25–100 μ m; Pharmacia), and reversed-phase C 18 silica gel (150–200 mesh, Merck) were used for column chromatography. Precoated silica gel GF-254 glass plates (Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Co. Ltd., Qingdao, China ) were used for TLC. The compounds were visualized under UV ( 254 nm ) light and by spraying with H 2 SO 4 –EtOH (1:9, v/v) and subsequently heating.

sec.title: 4.2. Plant material
sec.p:
Whole plants of
Odontoschisma grosseverrucosum Stephani (Cephaloziaceae)
were collected from Wuyanling National Nature Reserve (coordinates 119° 37′ 08’’ − 119° 50′ 00″ E , 27° 20′ 52’’ − 27° 48′ 39″ N , 1724 m a.s.l.), Lishui City, Zhejiang Province , People's Republic of China , in May 2018 (wet season), and they were identified by Dr. Jinchuan Zhou (College of Pharmacy, Linyi University). A voucher specimen (No. 20180518011) has been deposited at the Department of Natural Products Chemistry, School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Shandong University, People's Republic of China .

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p:
The air-dried and milled plant materials of
O. grosseverrucosum
(560.0 g) were extracted with 95% EtOH (3 × 1.5 L , each for one week) at room temperature and filtered. The filtrate was evaporated under a reduced pressure at 40 ° C to yield the crude extract ( 28.5 g ), which was separated via MCI gel column (12 × 3.3 cm ) chromatography (MeOH–H 2 O, 3:7 to 9:1) and yielded fractions 1–7. Fraction 2 ( 3.3 g ) was chromatographed using a silica gel column (9 × 3.3 cm ) [petroleum ether (60–90 ° C )-acetone, 200:1 to 0:1] to yield subfractions 2 A− 2 N. Subfraction 2 B ( 268.2 mg ) was purified using HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 73:27, 1.5 mL/min) to yield 1 ( 137.8 mg ) and 3 ( 6.9 mg ). Subfraction 2D ( 297.2 mg ) was subjected to an RP-C 18 silica gel column (10 × 1.8 cm ) (MeOH–H 2 O, 5:5 to 10:0) to yield subfractions A−F. Subfraction B was purified using HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 75:25, 1.5 mL/ min) to yield 4 (11.0 mg). Subfraction C was purified using HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 85:15, 1.5 mL/min) to yield 10 (7.0 mg). Subfraction 2 E ( 167.3 mg ) was applied to a Sephadex LH-20 column (110 × 1.8 cm ) (MeOH) and a RP-18 silica gel column (10 × 1.8 cm ) (MeOH/H 2 O, 5:5 to 10:0) to yield subfractions A−H. Subfraction E was purified via HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 75:25, 1.5 mL/min) to yield 5 ( 10.4 mg ). Subfraction D was purified via HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 73:27, 1.5 mL/min) to yield 2 ( 4.1 mg ) and 6 ( 1.3 mg ). Fraction 2G ( 115.9 mg ) was purified using HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 75:25, 1.5 mL/min) to yield 9 (18.0 mg). Fraction 2H (135.0 mg) was applied to a Sephadex LH-20 column (110 × 1.8 cm ) (MeOH) and a RP-18 silica gel column (10 × 1.8 cm ) (MeOH–H 2 O, 5:5 to 10:0), which was followed by purification with HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 70:30, 1.5 mL/min), to yield 8 ( 3.5 mg ). Fraction 3 ( 1.5 g ) was chromatographed using a silica gel column (8 × 3.3 cm ) [petroleum ether (60–90 ° C )-acetone, 200:1 to 0:1] to yield subfractions 3 A-3K. Fraction 3 A ( 419.2 mg ) was applied to a Sephadex LH-20 column (90 × 2.2 cm ) (MeOH), which was followed by purification with HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 80:20, 1.5 mL/min), to yield 7 (6.0 mg). All compounds were detected under UV ( 254 nm ) light and by spraying with H 2 SO 4 –EtOH (1:9, v/v) and heating.

sec.title: 4.3.1. Odongrossin A (1)
sec.p: Yellowish oil; [ α ] D 25 +3.2 ( c 0.30 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.80) nm; ECD (MeOH) 217 (Δ ε −1.42) nm; IR ν max 3504, 2933, 1713, 1454, 1360, 1163, and 962 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 329.2452 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 20 H 34 O 2 Na, 329.2451).

sec.title: 4.3.2. Odongrossin B (2)
sec.p: Yellowish oil; [ α ] D 25 +0.22 ( c 0.20 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 232 (2.93) nm; ECD (MeOH) 215 (Δ ε −0.25) nm; IR ν max 3351, 2940, 1451, 1382, 1143, 1049, and 964 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 281.2477 [M + H] + (calcd for C 18 H 33 O 2 , 281.2475).

sec.title: 4.3.3. Odongrossin C (3)
sec.p: Colourless crystals (MeOH); mp 73–74 ° C ; [ α ] D 25 −4.6 ( c 0.10 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 203 (3.78) nm, 286 (2.58) nm; ECD (MeOH) 228 (Δ ε −0.65) nm, 242 (Δ ε 0.19) nm; IR ν max 3348, 2965, 2927, 1764, 1501, 1250, 1007, and 882 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 283.1305 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 16 H 20 O 3 Na, 283.1305).

sec.title: 4.3.4. Odongrossin D (4)
sec.p: Colourless oil; [ α ] D 25 +43 ( c 1.00 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.36) nm; ECD (MeOH) 289 (Δ ε 0.19) nm, 203 (Δ ε −2.06) nm; IR ν max 3463, 3083, 2971, 2939, 2875, 1708, 1639, 1445, 918, and 891 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 327.2294 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 20 H 32 O 2 Na, 327.2295).

sec.title: 4.3.5. Odongrossin E (5)
sec.p: Colourless oil; [ α ] D 25 +13 ( c 0.05 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.41) nm; ECD (MeOH) 200 (Δ ε −2.06) nm; IR ν max 3352, 2938, 2902, 1594, 1026, 870, and 706 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 306.2550 [M] + (calcd for C 20 H 34 O 2 , 306.2553).

sec.title: 4.3.6. Odongrossin F (6)
sec.p: Colourless oil; [ α ] D 25 +12 ( c 0.05 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (2.84) nm; ECD (MeOH) 201 (Δ ε −2.03) nm, 228 (Δ ε 0.07) nm; IR ν max 3301, 2931, 2873, 1671, 1453, 1378, 1021, 859, and 700 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 306.2550 [M] + (calcd for C 20 H 34 O 2 , 306.2553).

sec.title: 4.3.7. Odongrossin G (7)
sec.p: Colourless oil; [ α ] D 25 +71 ( c 0.30 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.81) nm; ECD (MeOH) 231 (Δ ε −0.83) nm, 301 (Δ ε 2.15) nm; IR ν max 2968, 2932, 1711, 1641, 1465, 1383, 982, and 898 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 320.2581 [M + NH 4 ] + (calcd for C 20 H 34 O 2 N, 320.2584).

sec.title: 4.3.8. Odongrossin H (8)
sec.p: Colourless oil; [ α ] D 25 −10 ( c 0.05 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (2.80) nm, 257 (2.22) nm; ECD (MeOH) 217 (Δ ε −0.13) nm, 253 (Δ ε 0.14) nm; IR ν max 3406, 3080, 2930, 1770, 1453, 1377, and 909 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 336.2536 [M + NH 4 ] + (calcd for C 20 H 34 O 3 N, 336.2533).

sec.title: 4.4. X-ray crystallographic analysis of compound 3
sec.p: One suitable crystal of 3 was obtained via recrystallization from MeOH, and its structure was analysed using a Bruker D8 venture diffractometer. The crystal was maintained at 301 (2) K during data collection. The structure was solved with the ShelXS structure solution program using direct methods and refined with the ShelXL-2014/7 refinement package using least-squares minimization.

The following settings were used in all calculations: C 16 H 20 O 3 , M = 260.14 g /mol, monoclinic, space group P 21, a = 8.9681 (19) Å , b = 5.4929(10) Å , c = 14.623 (3) Å , β = 93.476 (8)°, V = 719.0 (2) Å 3 , Z = 2,
Dcalcd
= 1.202 g /cm 3 , μ (Mo K α ) = 0.711 mm −1 , F (000) = 280, and 3226 measured reflections (2.275° ≤ 2θ ≤ 26.017°), of which 2269 are unique. The final R 1 was 0.0562 (> 2sigma(I)), and wR 2 was 0.1421 (all data). The flack parameter was 1.6(10). The detailed crystallographic data for 3 have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication number CCDC 1967375. The data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/products/csd/request.

sec.title: 4.5. Strains and culture
sec.p: 4.6. Effect of compounds on the phenotypic transition of C. albicans

We examined the effects of compound s on hyphal growth using a modified broth microdilution (
).
C. albicans
strains DSY654 and SC5314 (1 × 10 5 cells/mL) were exposed to various concentrations of compounds (0–32 μ g/mL) in RPMI1640 and incubated at 37 °C without shaking. The morphology of
C. albicans
was observed by microscope (scale bars: 100 μ m) at 6 h.
4.7. Effect of compound 1 on the fungal adherence to A 549 cells

A 549 cells (2 × 10 4 cells/well) were cultured at 37 ° C for 24 h in the RPMI 1640 medium with 10% foetal bovine serum (FBS) and penicillin/streptomycin. Then, the supernatants were decanted, and the unbound cells were removed by washing the plates with PBS three times. In each well, 500 μ L of the
C. albicans DSY
654 cell suspension (1 × 10 6 cells/mL) that was mixed with a suitable concentration of 1 (0, 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32 μ g/mL) was plated. After the incubation at 37 ° C for 90 min, the supernatants were decanted, and the unbound cells were removed by washing the plates with PBS three times. Then, the cells were fixed for 30 min by using 4% paraformaldehyde, and the adherent
C. albicans
cells were stained with Calcofluor White. After staining, the unbound Calcofluor White was washed with PBS , and the adherent
C. albicans
cells were observed using an Olympus fluorescence microscope (scale bars: 100 μ m) and counted (
).
4.8. Effect of compound 1 on C. albicans biofilm formation

The effect of 1 on the biofilm formation of
C. albicans
strain DSY654 was tested via a CCK-8 reduction assay in 96-well microtiter plates (
). A 100- μ L DSY654 cell suspension (1 × 10 6 cells/mL in RPMI1640 medium) was added to a 96-well flat-bottom plate with concentrations of 0, 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32 μ g/mL of compound 1 , and 2 μ g/ mL of FLC served as the positive control. After the plates were incubated at 37 °C for 24 h, the supernatants were discarded, and the nonadhered cells were removed by washing three times with PBS. To a 96- well plate, 100 μ L of PBS buffer and 10 μ L of the CCK-8 solution were added, and the samples were incubated for 4 h at 37 °C. The absorbance at a wavelength of 450 nm (OD450) was measured, and images of the effect of 1 on the biofilms were captured by an Olympus fluorescence microscope (Olympus IX71, Olympus, Tokyo , Japan ). (scale bars: 100 μ m).
4.9. Real-time RT-PCR analysis

sec.title: Declaration of competing interests
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: This work was supported financially by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Nos. 81874293, 81630093, and 81773786). The authors are grateful to Mr. S. Q. Wang for the NMR measurements, Mrs. J. Xing for the HRESIMS measurements, and Ms. J. Z. Zhang and Dr. Y. N. Qiao for the structural determination via single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

sec.title: Appendix A . Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2020.112341.
